title: Another teenage-audience focused movie
text: So, the story starts weak from the beginning, simplistic post-apocalypse society which is not really believable, and lacks of depth and sense, leaving lots of questions from the beginning in the viewer's head. Even if you get pass over that, the development is the typical teenager put in the typical challenges (training, bullies, self-improvement, lover boy, parent problems...), in the typical oppressor society, which could be fine if better thought. On top of that, the music tries so blatantly to catch teenagers to buy the soundtrack that made me roll my eyes. Absolutely nothing new regarding story and script. If you're interested in seeing some action movie for the while, it's OK until the last 30/40 minutes, that gets so obvious and predictable that is hardly watchable. If that half hour wasn't that bad, I would have liked it a bit more, but it really feels rushed up, even if the movie lasts two hours twenty minutes, looks like a loot happens in the end, when not much in the beginning took too long to develop. The actors are fine for what hey had to do, but there's not much to see here. Good acting, fair photography, weak story and writing. Nothing missed if unseen.

title: Why didn't Tris just kill Jeanine?
text: Obviously, there probably wouldn't have been two more books/movies if Tris had killed Jeanine, but c'mon, really? It's not like she didn't have the chance to at the end of the movie to just shoot her instead of just knocking her out. It really annoyed me. Honestly, if I had just witnessed both of my parents dying, you better be damn sure the person who was responsible got theirs. Tris could have killed her and then in the second installment there was a new person who was set out to destroy divergents, fueled by revenge or something or just even sticking to the original reason of feeling threatened by them. The ending just didn't do it for me, and for that, I haven't watched the 2nd one. Perhaps, I may if I happen to catch it on TV, but other than that, with the ending of Divergent, I just wasn't interested to find out what happened next. Anyone else feel this way?

title: Divergent (Part1)
text: Divergent revolves around a dystopian world where everyone is split into different factions and i think this couldve been portrayed much better. The acting in this movie is incredibly mid and it forces you to be hit with a feeling of second hand embarrassment. If this movie had a different actor for the main character i think it wouldve been slightly better. Unfortunately, divergent on the whole has an undescribable feeling of cringe when watching it. Theo James character is one of the only enjoyable actor in this movie even with it including the likes of Miles Teller and Ansel Egort. But maybe im wrong and it's incredible to others. All opinion based.

title: Wasn't that impressed! 4/10
text: Review: Man, this film is way to long and I wasn't that impressed with the storyline or the whole concept. The director wasted so much time on the training and I expected the main character to be something special but she just turned out to be like the other candidates. Anyway, the acting wasn't anything special but it was good to see Kate Winslet play a baddie for once. The director gave the movie a big build at the beginning but by the end, it was all a bit pointless. It just seemed a bit over complicated and after a while it seemed to drag and become uninteresting. The 5 different factions didn't really come into play because the director concentrated on the girl keeping her secret and falling in love with the trainer. Maybe the whole story will unfold in the sequel which is bound to come out soon, but I won't be rushing to see it. Disappointing!Round-Up: This movie did get a big distribution and it looked good in the adverts which is why it made so much money. After watching the movie the film does seem like there is a loads of information missing, but I wasn't that bothered to be honest. The love story was really predictable and the action scenes wasn't that realistic. On the plus side, there is a deep moral to the story about equality and everyone becoming one but apart from that, the director really does need to use the profit to make a better sequel because the concept needs a lot of work. Budget: $85million Worldwide Gross: $275millionI recommend this movie to people who are into there futuristic, sci-fi adventure movies about 5 different factions, which have been separate by personality type, and 1 girl making the decision of were she belongs. 4/10

title: Bad Books, Bad Show
text: On its own, it might not have been a bad movie. However, since I read the book first, I had no choice but to compare the two. Both are pretty weak, standard young-adult novels. In a film scene permeated by movies such as The Hunger Games and The Maze Runner (which is easily a superior series of books), Divergent lacks the appeal of the other two by not having characters that seem real.

Not as bad as i thought it would be, yet still not satisfying. In this movie stuff just happens, there is close to none logical sense in the continuity of scene to scene and huge shortcuts on the story which by itself is pretty uninteresting and brings nothing new to the table. Character motivations are unclear or unconvincing and the character themselves are either clichéd, cheesy or banal and are portrayed with equal dullness with the exception of Tris, who at least feels rounded thanks to a very good performance by Shailene Woodley, and whilst Four is miles away from being a real character, Theo James brings some very healthy charisma to the screen. The movie is filled with contradictions and minor plot holes that all add up to very poor storytelling. However the movie managed to be mildly engaging and times and even comes close to be exciting with a couple of enthralling sequences with great set-pieces. The film looks pretty neat and there is a very good cinematography which managed to keep me involved in what ever was going on, I have to give a shout out to the score too. Yet I can't stress enough how chaotic everything regarding characters, story and plot feels. This all culminates in a very dull third act with and equally uninspired ending. Sometimes this "stuff" that happens is actually good, other times it's stupid but laughable (in the first act I was laughing my ass off in the sequences that included the Dauntless and the train, I'm still laughing now), but for the most part it's distracting or and makes you cringe. I have to say that at least you can feel the director is trying o make a good movie and has actual interest for the material and as I said there is some fun to be had, but all in all it just felt mediocre. I don't know if the book is good or not since I have not read it, but it does feel like it borrows some ideas from other pre-existing franchises.

title: Could not get into it
text: Because I could not suspend belief in the far fetched system, I just could not get into it.The action scenes were OK but I did not care for the Characters and so was bored.

title: Great book, very bad movie
text: After reading a book I had quite high expectations before seeing movie. I was so badly disappointed. Although the book is great, you get a full information about background, why Tris chose what she chose. There are important friendships and characters that were totally ignored by movie creators. I wonder how they will solve this problem in future parts, I suspect that some people will just show up out of a blue, no one will know how they were connected. The biggest mistake was to ignore character of Peter, he is a Draco Malfoy of this trilogy and he is important although a villain. Hunger Games already proved that you can stick to the book and make a good, reasonably long movie. With those creators all we get is a sequence of unconnected scenes. Such shame.

title: Bland and unconvincing
text: I read the book a few years ago when I was still a young adult, the demographic this was aimed towards. I remember finding the story implausible and the writing uninspiring, so I never got around to reading the sequels. However, when I saw the trilogy on Amazon Prime, I thought 'Why not?' as I was curious to see what direction the story had taken.My first impression was, as others have stated, that this is a rip-off of The Hunger Games, but without the compelling bits: the self-sacrifice of Katniss for her sister, the stark contrast with the silly materialism of the upper class, the complex relationship with the two male leads, the actual feeling of danger and impending death. When characters did die, I wasn't invested in them enough to care. As such, the film is predictable and uncaptivating and fails to distinguish itself.The interaction and relationships between characters is also unconvincing, in particular between Four and Tris: there is no build-up and no chemistry. Also, I'm not entirely certain why, but the lead actresses in most of these young adult book-turned-films seem to portray their characters with as few facial expressions as is possible. It seems that this is somehow meant to convey a quiet strength or perhaps a lack of a happy and secure upbringing but it just comes across as bad acting. I could not connect with Tris nor feel her struggle at all. Or any of the other characters.As for the plot, I don't understand how human beings can last 200 years without rebellion and war, living within a faction system that favours only one of their individual attributes over all others. Certainly there would have been much dissatisfaction and they would have been at each others' throats much sooner? Humans are multifaceted; are Divergents truly that rare? Much of this is sort of explained at the start of the third film, but why should I have to watch two boring films and then one more to finally understand the main premise of the story? The film hence drags on, and there's seemingly no sense to anything they are doing.By itself, the film is nothing more than teenagers engaging in single combat, armed parkour, and whatever else is 'cool' these days. As usual, the future is in the hands of the young people, while the only adult characters either end up dead or are the bad guys. A tiny girl with little body mass fights and overpowers trained men. Also, no bullets or permanent harm seem to touch the main leads, because... well, plot.In the end, this film is like an extremely long prologue. You're left with questions that you couldn't be bothered to have answered because that would mean watching the next two films. (I subsequently ended up watching them not because I cared, but because I wanted something uncaptivating to play in the background while I did some reading.)

title: Good but not that good
text: It is a good movie but it has nothing on the book. I saw the movie when it came out but after just reading the book and now reawatching the movie i am extreamly dissappinted. They changed so many things, added new things and removed important details. The cast is also not what the book describes. Trish is supposed to be small and very shy and grow into a warrior. In the movie Trish is is outspoken och average in fighting from the start. Molly and Peter which are supported to be huge bullies are portrayed as irritating mean children. In the book Trish is seriously scared of them but the movie makes molly seem like Trish in the book.Janeane is taking too much screentime, she's supposed to be undercover evil. But you can clearly understand she is the villain in the movie.The relationship between Trish and Four was also changed, as was the Dauntless strictness, rules and traditions.In the book the first half is all about not failing the initiation and hints of growing interest between Trish and Four. The difficulty of making it is almost none in the movie while in the book multiple people died during this period. The competition between initiatives is also totally removed in the movie.Conclusion: it's not a bad movie but it is nothing compared to the book. It seems like the director looked at the book more as a suggestion when making the movie.

title: Preadolescent
text: Warning: if you are an adult or a young person that can read actual literature, this is not a movie for you. The premise of the movie can appeal only to those who know very little about human nature and the story never really picks above juvenile cliches.

title: Seriously, guys. THIS is what you wanted?
text: I'm just surprised that you anticipated this more than Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles. Thinking about it now, this might be a good thing, mainly because TMNT is a far inferior movie. But just because I say that this movie is slightly better than the aftermentioned TMNT, that doesn't mean it gets a pass.Unfortunately, there's too many signs that they were clearly lacking a lot of things in Divergent, since there is a lot to be desired. The story is predictable and full of cliches and plot holes as far as they eye can see, the visuals don't take much advantage of its $80 million budget, the pacing can be really slow with this film's 2 hour 20 minute runtime, and the characters are onenote tropes you'd expect in films like these. Not to mention that it feels all too similar to other young adult fiction titles of its kind. The books may have been popular, but when we have films like The Hunger Games, it isn't fair to call yourself original when somebody else came before you.But even if Divergent is a bad movie, I think it goes without saying that this is NOT the worst action film I've seen in my life. Far from it. To the movie's credit, most of the fight scenes are engaging and when the film wants to indulge in the action, the execution of the fights can be fun and easy to get into, and the concept does sound engaging at first glance, most particularly to the most die-hard fans of the dystopian genre. That, and the best aspect of the film is the acting. The cast here did a great job with the materials presented, such as Theo James, Miles Teller, Ashley Judd, Ansel Elgort, Kate Winslet, Maggie Q, Zoe Kravitz, and especially the headlining star Shailene Woodley, who's probably the best actress of the movie. It's just too bad that talented actors like these have to work with materials that are of such poor taste, that I'm sure their talents are worth much more than anything developed from a failed film like this!Conclusion? Predictable story + uninteresting concept + meh visuals + fun action + forgettable characters + great acting = Divergent the movie.

title: Way Too Long
text: Not a bad movie. Didn't need to be 2hrs 20. Would have been better suited at 90 minutes.

title: Teenage girl only
text: Like Twilight, this movie is made to appeal teenage girls, and is as senseless as you could imagine.Is not that they made it also for other audiences. They did not care.If you like ready to nervously giggle meanwhile the dude touches the girl hand, then watch this movie. Otherwise, punching your fingers with a hammer would be more entertaining.It is predictable.Everything goes well for the teen girl because she's predestined to be THE GIRL.Of course she's the good girl because she opens his eyes big, and looks nice.The evil is also a women, but a mature one, ¿so it feels like the girl can crush the competence? I don't know. It smells to estrogen probably.I must confess that I didn't even bothered to watch the last 20 minutes. It was not worth it.

title: Find Another Film To Watch
text: I've not read the books but if the film is anything to go on I won't be rushing out to buy them anytime soon.I know this is a dystopian story set in the future but I can't class it as a Science Fiction movie as the entire story concept is implausible. I cannot believe the human race would reduce itself into five factions which are segregated by a test, but then they get to choose which faction they want to join. Not only are the factions designated by job, but by uniform, colour, and even their homes. They are not allowed any personal items as that might bring forth human nature. Imagine Humans being Human, what a notion!The acting is just okay, even the bigger name actors, Ashley Judd, Maggie Q, Ray Stephenson, and Kate Winslet couldn't lift this film out of the morass the story and direction placed it in.I don't know how they could've made the movie any better other than a total rewrite and refilm.However, the action sequences aren't too bad except for the fight training... doesn't anybody remember Martial Arts in this stupid, segregated, and insanely dull future world(?)I wouldn't recommend this flick to anyone. There are loads of better films out there, go watch Hercules starring Dwayne Johnson, so much more entertaining.

title: Better than Hunger Games I suppose.
text: Divergent is another one of those big cast adaptations of best selling books that no one has eve heard of until the movie comes out.I mean, I think I am in the loop with all things, but I never did hear of this one.That said, and with my hatred of The Hunger Games, I still give this one a go...Without being as cheesy and annoying as THG, Divergent focuses more on the bigger picture. Different societies as opposed to children, have issues with each other. Of course, there is the love story, although a bit later on which is good, and plenty of annoying characters who you don't mind seeing killed off if and when it happens.The main cast is quite fresh faced still, but like those of THG, I didn't really take to them and didn't get much screen presence from them at all.The film is watchable. Its far from the best thing out there, but it passes the time and has a few enjoyable moments.I wouldn't rush out to get it, but if you are bored, give it a go!

title: A Real Snoozer
text: The real shame of this film is that the beginning was decent... and then it fell apart. There was no real character development of which to speak. By the end of the film you feel you *still* don't get the main characters. The acting seemed forced (especially on Kate Winslet's part), and there was no real storyline. I checked out the book to see whether it was a problem on the part of the author or the screenplay. The original material was incredibly poorly written. The redeeming quality of this film comes in the random details, such as Four's tattoo.

title: Stop making the same movie over and over
text: How can they keep making Hunger Games movies and just call them different things?

title: Way to make a bad book terrible
text: Unoriginal book made worse by Hollywood scriptwriting. Main characters have no chemistry between them which was the only reason worth reading or watching divergent.

title: Potter + Twilight + Hunger Games + Harlequin Romance = Vomit
text: My title summons up my feeling for this movie.I could tell in the first 15 minutes I was going to hate it. But wife wanted to see it so I had to sit through it, plus I thought "okay maybe somewhere maybe this movie might improve"..it never did.The worst problem I had with it was it was way too fantasy, unbelievable. Like from the start: So they run along this train..then you see "oh, whew just in time!", yea right!If you are a person who knows anything about anything you will see there are just to many holes in this. Example if you know anything about trapeze arts you know you must land on the net just the right way (not on your head, or feet first, etc.) else you would probably end up crippled or even killed.Then anyone who knows anything about martial arts would see this so called advanced fighting technique of the future laughable. For that matter if you have the slightest understanding of physics you'ed see a lot of stuff happening improbable, if not downright impossible. And then shouldn't there be bodies all over the place with such reckless abandon? I could go on and on, it's like the writer(s) of this movie were in some sort of hallucinogenic stupor while they wrote it. The key parts of the story they seemed to have "borrowed" from other trendy stories like the first book of Harry Potter, the Twilight concept, and a fair bit of Hunger Games thrown in.Also the whole movie is very stereotyped and predictable. You could literally see what was going to happen a mile away.Finally that literally got me nauseated was the way over the top dramatic and sappiness of it. Somewhere between the worst soap opera and some sort of teenaged "reality" show. I'm pretty sure this story was geared for teenage girls, or otherwise I'm not sure what they were thinking.In the end my wife liked it (whom is not a teenager by the way), but I wouldn't recommend this movie to anyone other then a 14 year old girl..I got to stop thinking and writing about this movie before I hurl..

title: A complete unoriginal failure
text: I simply hate these pretentious teenage book adaptations , so you can tell I wasn't happy going to see this thing.It started just like a 'Hunger Games' rip-off, with a much dumber idea and a completely uninterested cast doing ( What I think is a) decent acting, the plot feels very familiar and it is so formulaic, Tris, played by Shailene Woodley, is one of the worst characters of the year, and must choose between five factions, which you won't give a crap about, and apparently she is a divergent, which you'll also won't give a crap about, meets a boy, and they will, obviously, fight the system...As you have noticed Divergent's plot is horribly unfocused and too long for it's own sake , the movie doesn't work and... well just don't watch it, it isn't worthy of your hard earned cash.

title: Lots of money peed up the wall.
text: 4 out of 10 because it is not bad enough to enjoy it in a wrong way. Utter mediocrity of a common garden variety, political correctness and cheesy acting does not qualify.Total waste of bandwidth if you download it illegally too. Makes you wonder in what derogatory terms film producers discuss the target audience.Don't really think that current 13-year-olds are THAT bad.I watched it out of curiosity - what buttons the "creative forces" behind this commercial enterprise are trying to push, but I want my time back as they managed to miss even the most obvious ones.

title: My divergent quiz results
text: When Divergent came out I read through the book like the wind spiraling out of control the image was so surreal that I imagined myself what it looked like in ruined Chicago. The setting starts out showing all the tall buildings in ruin then the colorful fashion of each faction Candor being black and white, Abnegation gray, Dauntless black, Erudite blue, and Amity red and yellow. Veronica Roth's ideal principle shared the different types of personality traits that coexists in all of us and the many ways we show, express, and model it. Personality the combination of characteristics or qualities that form an individual's distinctive character helps people observe and reflect a persons behavior and the instincts they have. After I finished the book I took the quiz and resulted in being divergent in three of the factions like Tris–I tested in  Abnegation, Dauntless, and Erudite because of all my traits put together. For a couple of months I thought of this all the time but now I see how these factions impacted me through life. While I admired the fact that I'm selfless, brave, and intelligent compared to Veronica Roth's Tris Prior in Divergent I thought a lot about my strengths, values, and accomplishments since. Sometimes I would imagine life in the faction system dedicated to hard work and trying to fit in but though I find myself wondering why divergence isn't allowed in society while others know what exactly they are. Some have a combination of many factions but nevertheless would we as people understand that we are improving everyday.I see myself in many shades of gray, a little aquamarine in Erudite and as always black as Dauntless, somehow I manage to fit in various factions rather being in one category  that makes up a person. Where would I get my inelegance from and the bravery that comes with it? Abnegation is out of the question because being selfless isn't the same as learning to be someone either than yourself. What would people think of me? These questions we ask ourselves.

title: Teenagers - a must; Grown-ups - a must not
text: As the movie went on and on the more disappointed I was. I ended up having to watch it in two parts since it bore me to death. It's all Déjà Vu. An attempt to copy the idea from The Hunger Games, which is not necessarily a bad thing, if they didn't totally fail at it. What we have as a result is a lame copy, with poor visual effects and a really (and I mean really) bad choice of protagonist. While the man is going to have a lot of teenage girls fans, her appearance is just not adequate for the character she is supposed to represent, and in my humble opinion she failed in trying to look bad-ass. The plot is flawed, pretty shallow and not arising any emotions.Will give the second sequel a chance to prove me wrong, although that is hardly possible, since I think the whole movie needs to be redone in order to make it better.

title: A plot that doesn't live up to its title
text: The basis of the film seems to be that choice is the key to being human, yet what looks be a fast paced, action packed running/jumping/shooting flick, feels like watching a mash up of so many other similar stories as though the characters have no choice.Following a brief introduction outlining, how after a world war, society in Chicago is split into factions, each providing a service to the whole of society, but seemingly completely separate in the way they run their lives. Following that, you have a Harry Potter sorting hat style scene and then the rest of the film follows the Twilight/Underworld/Hunger Games plot of a young couple against the system. Throw in some unresolved parenting/sibling issues, some Inception style CGI, Kate Winslet walking around like Jodie Foster in Elysium, and Maggie Q as, well, she's in the film, and it's easy to see who the target audience are; it's a teen flick. Demonstrating the fact, casting Ben Lloyd-Hughes and Christian Madsen and dressing them in identical clothes, could have been a statement on the state of society and how people may look a like, but can act differently. Yet sadly the acting and camera work made it too hard to tell who had done what! The film is based on a series of books, but compared to the first Hunger Games film, it doesn't seem fleshed out enough to continue the story on.

title: Divergent feels average but is somehow compelling
text: Divergent is a very frustrating film. I'm giving it 5/10 because it feels just too average.I wouldn't call the story/plot original. The premise has kind of been done before albeit in different ways.The acting is average even from the Shailene Woodley (who I rate). Kate Winslett is a flop. Ashley Judd would have played Kate's part much better and come to think of it, Kate Winslett would have played Ashley Judd's part better too.Because I generally like this genre of movie, I will be giving the sequel a go. I hope it's better because there are two more coming after that too!

title: A carbon copy that occasionally pleases.
text: It seems as though the standard for Hollywood today is to throw money at any film adaptation of a popular young adult novel that might make a profit. Most of these films center around an innocent lead character born into a supernatural or futuristic world who is forced to overcome many obstacles, almost always finding love along the way. The craze started with the Harry Potter franchise, which was later succeeded by box office hits such as Twilight, The Hunger Games and their countless sequels. But now that the romantic spark of Bella and Edward has died down and the next visit to Panem isn't due until late 2014, teenage audiences have been left searching for another young adult movie train to hop onto (members of Dauntless should be informed that this pun was intended). Lucky for them, the search is over with Divergent, a film in which the performances and premise are almost too good for the reputation its arrogant critics are bound to give it.In Divergent, Tris is played by the immensely talented Shailene Woodley (she starred in the young adult adaptation of The Spectacular Now and audiences can watch her again later this year on the big screen in yet another young adult adaptation, The Fault in Our Stars). Tris lives in a world where everyone is separated into groups, or factions, and she has finally gotten to the age where she must wear the Sorting Hat and find out whether she belongs to Gryffindor... correction: Tris must consume a serum that will recommend to her which of the five factions she should join: Abnegation, Amity, Candor, Erudite, or Dauntless. When her results come up as unclear, she discovers that she is a Divergent and is considered a threat to the society of future dystopian Chicago. Instead of listening to her results, Tris joins Dauntless and begins jumping off of buildings for fun. This is where she meets a well-built and tough man, Four (I Am Number Four, anyone?), who also enjoys jumping off of buildings for fun. He cuts her ear with a knife in one of their early encounters, which would obviously lead to Tris falling head over heels for him. When the two realize that their feelings are shared, they team up to fight against the leader of Erudite, played by Kate Winslet, and stop her from killing everyone in Tris' original faction, Abnegation.There were two groups of people, or factions, in the crowd when Divergent was screening in the theater: there were the audience members who truly wanted to analyze the film and see what all the craze was about, and then there were the teenage girls that giggled and cheered when they looked up from their cell phones to see Theo James take his shirt off. People who are part of the latter group will love the parts of this movie they look up to see regardless. But if audiences really want to see a quality film, they still may find some aspects to enjoy here. For example, the performances from an A-list cast are outstanding. Shailene Woodley and Theo James gave their all to their performances both through physical training and emotional line-delivery. Kate Winslet portrayed a villain whose path no one would like to cross. Even though the performances were exceptional, the characters did not seem as well developed as they could've been. This should be an easy fix though considering the next two sequels already have release dates. Neil Burger's direction of the action sequences is very well executed. He avoids jerking the camera around aimlessly as so many current directors do to make choreography easier and instead allows the audience to see what they want to see. The adapted screenplay by Evan Daugherty and Vanessa Taylor is nothing special, but it did the job of compressing the 496 page book into a 150 minute runtime. Though some of the testing sequences were poorly done due to an overuse of cheesy special effects, they are easy to overlook seeing as they only take up a good five or so minutes of the final runtime. Divergent is not a perfect film, but it leaves ample room for questions to be answered and characters to be developed further in future entries, and it undoubtedly lives up to its name when being compared to other films of the genre. For those who just cannot wait until next March to see the sequel, a trailer for The Maze Runner, the newest young adult adaptation, was conveniently played before every Divergent screening. Be prepared to push through heaping crowds of adolescents to purchase tickets.

title: Wow
text: Read this awesome book and than I saw this movie. Couldn't even finish watching it.

title: Diverting... but it doesn't quite hit the mark and it's just too familiar.
text: To me, 2014 seems to be the year of the shallow attempt to recapture the financial magic of "The Hunger Games". First you had "Divergent" and then you had "Maze Runner"---and all three games are aimed at the same audience and are pretty much the same movie in so many ways. All are set in a manipulative futuristic dystopia and all are aimed at creating franchises that will bring in the audiences like lemmings--ready to toss wads of cash at the studios.

title: Predictable ::
text: Totally predictable one, I must say. I predicted almost every steps the director made in this movie.No new concepts are there that you can expect from this type of high- budget movie. It's a kind of Pop-corn type, you can say.I think the script writer influenced by "Hunger Games" to write this type of copy-cat. A high budget "Copy-paste" type, others can say.Without a rich script, none can direct a good movie. So this one maintains that universal rule, nothing else.How this type of film rated 7 on IMDb, I don't know! I can rate hardly 3 out of 10 for this one. And I am quite sure about that.

title: Just another Hunger Games - with less good actors
text: The background/theme of the plot is intriguing, but not the moral arising from it; first, there are many who would prefer "organized" life, and second, there are enough professional and lifestyle dynasties. Abstract freedom is not for everyone, and due to family or disability, many people would choose not to make rustles here and there... Anyway, this benchmark could launch an interesting movie, but what we see is getting entangled in clichés and mostly trivial performances, actors-actresses based on looks (apart from Shailene Woodley and "older" generation actors). There are some twists, but having seen about half- an-hour, you will be pretty sure who will have crush on whom, who will not survive, etc., but many of them whose acting could be pleasurable spend too little time on screen (particularly Ashley Judd and Kate Winslet). And a closed society with hostile outside world - not a very novel one, and there is no contact between them (perhaps in sequels?). Thus, in general, Divergent is an expensive hype made for young audiences who would like to identify themselves with the characters depicted mostly in good vs. bad, brave vs. craven manner.

title: Snore.
text: My wife and I chose this film on a date night because it seemed to be the best option at the local theater,which isn't saying much.I'm not much on futuristic films,but I gave this one a whirl anyhow.I guess the fact that Kate Winslet was in it had something to do with that,seeing as how she is one of my favorite actresses,and this time,she's a bad girl.The rest of the cast,I couldn't say I was familiar with.The final verdict,given everything I just said was one you might expect.I was completely dulled out by this film.Not even Kate could save me from wanting my money back.So much for an exciting date night.Oh well,the wife and I had each other,which is always great!

title: good for teenagers. sort of Twilight for dystopians
text: I can understand that this movie is probably aimed at teenagers and I, being 39, have failed miserably, choosing to watch this movie. Everything, from (most of) soundtrack, to writing, to directing, is cheesy.i expected to watch an enjoyable dystopic movie, but all in all it fell into the "let's have some action, but still love wins" category, with all the possible clichés of this kind of movies, except the classic "oh wait, my beloved, I'm not really dead after all" moment.I should have really read a bit more about this movie, so that I would have certainly discarded it, as the premises (the division of people into five separated categories), could be interesting, but it is almost certain that it is not going to remain credible for an entire movie, and in fact it appeared after just some minutes that it was going to be a boring and senseless movie. for the sake of intellectual honesty, I decided to watch it all in order to write this review: grown-up people, stay away from this movie.

title: A silly world with silly people.
text: I watched this movie although I've been told I shouldn't. "It's both stupid and boring" But after seeing it and I can now somewhat understand my friends statement, although I do not totally agree. It's not stupid, it just needs more work and time. And it's not boring, just irritating and illusive in it's fictitious rules. This movie is one of plenty movies that follows the "Youth in a futuristic world." I really like the idea and Hunger Games did it fantastic. I really sets the right mood and the storytelling seems "logic" in it's turns and twists. Although Divergent didn't. For the most part of the movie I got bored. Some of the drastic turns or dramatic scenes seemed illogical and they felt forced to get the story forwards. And them scenes are just irritating and you just ask yourself why they couldn't get a more credible or comprehending storytelling without these forced scenes. Although they had some scenes that moved the story forward in a great way, which that captured your attention. And this fictitious world with the different factions just felt... silly...

title: adaptation is real bad
text: Read the book before watching movie. movie seems like a trailer of the book with spoiler

title: A Different Version of the Hunger Games
text: Having read the book and seen the movie,obviously,I can say that this movie adaptation of the book by Veronica Roth does the justice to the book. So does this mean that the movie is successful? Well, in general this does not apply to all adaptations, however, for Divergent the answer is a simple yes.Not only does it do the justice to the book but also is a successful movie within itself. This is due to the good acting, setting, and successful directing of Neil Burger. The movie does not bore the viewer even though it is more than 2 hours long. So if you're looking for adventure without intense fight scenes then Divergent is a really good choice.

title: well its there
text: Fun at times stupid as well. Acting is simple but ok. Dum at times, could be good but its fair.

title: Thoroughly enjoyable
text: I rate Divergent 9 out of 10 stars because I was fully engaged and entertained white watching the film.Woodley's Tris is a sympathetic protagonist that allows the viewer to see the new world order through fresh eyes. She is instantly relatable. Teller's Peter is a likable antagonist that I would have liked to see in a different role, yet he performed well. Courtney's Eric is very hard to like, which I was a bit disappointed in. I think my impression going in was that he played a bigger part. James' Four is a difficult, guarded young man with a soft spot for divergent girls like Tris, or perhaps only Tris. (I've never read the book/s this is based off of). As a sci-fi/fantasy genre story, I had no problem buying into the reality the film presented. As far as comparing it to other young adult popular fiction turned into films, I'd say it is more engaging and better acted than The Hunger Games. However, I'd say this isn't just for a set audience of teen girls or teens, but adults as well. It really poses a major question about society and how we lead our lives.

title: "The Hunger Games" 2.0 - but not as good
text: The "Divergent" series of novels, which started to appear in 2011, owes a great deal to "The Hunger Games" collection, which began to be published in 2008. Both are three works aimed at young adults and written by female American authors (in the case of "Divergent", Veronica Roth). Both have a principled and plucky 16 year old heroine (in "Divergent", Beatrice 'Tris' Prior). Both are set in a post-apocalyptic dystopian world located in the former United States (in "Divergent", an enclosed Chicago). Both involve societies strictly divided (in the case of "Divergent", into five factions based on different human attributes). Both mix violence and romance in an exploration of coming of age and discovery of identity. And both are being turned into four money-making movies.I have read the three "HG" novels and seen the two (so far) films and so, while not having read the "Divergent" books, I was happy to give this first spin-off film a go. I don't think it packs the punch of its rival but it's certainly entertaining enough. As with the "HG" movies, an absolutely key ingredient is the casting of the central heroine. Again we don't have quite the talent that is Jennifer Lawrence as Katniss, but Shailene Woodley - whom I first spotted in "The Descendents"- is an appealing young actress of genuine potential and 2014, which saw her in "The Faults In Our Stars" as well as "Divergent", is definitely her take-off year.

title: Breathtaking Movie~!
text: Jeanine Mathews: "You're a poor blend of impulses and impurities." The storyline is based upon the novel written by the 25 years old Veronica Roth. The novel is a totalitarian dystopia and it showcased how teenagers are trained to fight, kill and rebel against dictatorship. This novel is directed into a movie by Neil Burger, casting the three main characters, Shailene Woodley as Tris (Beatrice), Theo James as Four and Jeanine Matthews (Cast: Kate Winslet), the dictator who ruled the 5 factions of citizens. The main theme of the novel and movie starts with the word "Divergent" where in the movie was referred to as someone who behaves and interacts differently from the rest of the populations. As described in the quote, divergent is an impurity and black sheep of the society. Therefore they are hunted down by the dictator Jeanine Mathews.The populations were diversified into 6 factions. The Abnegation, Erudite, Dauntless, Amity, and Candor which represents selflessness, intelligence, bravery, peace, honesty respectively. Not to be mentioned, those that do not belong to any factions which are homeless and less- fortunate are known as the faction-less group of people. Teenagers are testified to categorize themselves into factions that they belong to, based upon their natural reactions toward fear and judged upon their tactics used during the test. Those whose test results are inconclusive are known as divergent. Tris and Four are the two main characters who did their best to find out why divergents are taken down and the main reason of destroying all divergents. As it is necessary to hear about people's perspectives and ideas about movies, I talked to those who went for Divergent before I did. Regardless of all those negative comments on both movie goers and readers, I made it to the movie. I was really surprise to find out that this Sci-Fi movie was actually using less computer graphics throughout compared to Hunger Games. I admit that the plot and storyline is pretty similar to Hunger Game but if it is compared to Hunger games, it is actually more tactical and unique. If you've watched Hunger Games, you know exactly what you're supposed to expect out of the movie. However, with "Divergent," you just have to watch and feel that excitement with Tris until you found out what was going on. Especially when the setting of the whole movie was under a deep hollow cave than the deep forest like Hunger Games. The major character, Tris is just like a tour guide of the movie taking you from the finding of divergent to discovering the reason behind diminishing all these divergents. I like about the part where Tris was being really naïve and being unprepared about what is going to happen around her and with the people whom she trusts. The movie keeps me excited and makes me think who the good ones and the bad ones are. The movie use short synopsis and does not reveal the twists of the plot until the ending. In addition to the plot, Ellie Goulding's song, "Dead in the water" had really expressed the inner side of Tris. I was really thrilled by how that song matches Tris's inner feeling. Overall, the movie is sensational and breathtaking in a way that you would not even want to compare it with Hunger Game. I should say that the movie is more realistic and make me thought about the possibility of such synopsis happening in the mere future. Another credit to the movie would be the fact that there was less romance compared to any other teenage movies I had watched so far. It portrayed more of dilemma between trust and mistrust in a relationship than the overwhelming romance that people dream about. You really don't want to miss a movie that is more realistic and active than Divergent. I would strongly recommend this to teenagers and parents as it is very heart-touching with less romance and more tactics. It is more like a mind training movie and motivation for teenagers than violence.

title: cast is good but the execution isn't
text: In a futuristic, dystopian Chicago society is divided into five factions--Erudite: who value knowledge, Amity: projectors of kindness and harmony, Candor: orderly truth tellers, Dauntless: the fearless and free who protect and police, Abnegation: simple and selfless stiffs who run the government. Found among the latter group is the unassuming Woodley who doesn't have a true sense of where she belongs. When her aptitude test proves dangerously inconclusive, she joins Dauntless hoping to conceal her abilities, which becomes difficult as she progresses through her training. Well-cast but ponderous sci-fi saga is intriguing at first then spends too much time rambling on about ominous warnings and trying to build a romantic subplot while ignoring more relevant story points and developing some key characters. Turns sappy in its final act and moves at a brisk pace that leaves many plot threads unanswered. **

title: Warning to readers: Contains SPOILERS
text: DIVERGENT (2014) In the future humanity is separated into five groups called factions. In this world civilization is based on these factions represented by the human virtues: Abnegation the selfless, Dauntless the courageous, Erudite the intellectual, Candor the truthful, and Amity the passive. When a member of this civilization becomes a teenager they are administered an invasive test to tell them what category they fit into. After the test the individual may choose his or her path, even if it is not the virtue the test revealed them to be in. The main character Tris, (AKA Stiff) played by Shailene Woodley, is revealed to be a divergent which means she does not fit in just one of these faction category, she is a combination of all of them, this is a threat to the order of civilization. Tris chooses to become Dauntless where she meets her soon to be boyfriend Four, played by Theo James. Together they embark on the impossible journey of overthrowing the government, and disengaging the devious leadership that controls the world they live in. The music in the movie is clear, especially in the powerful scenes during the beginning of the film when the Dauntless characters are introduced. The sounds of their actions are heightened with every move as they run through the crowed and scale a very high wall to jump aboard an extremely fast moving train headed to the Dauntless training facility. The audience can feel the sound effects giving them the sensation of being right there with the characters as they perform these daunting task. They give the viewer an emotional connection with the characters bringing a sense of reality to the film. Visual elements are eye candy for the viewer. There are masses of natural light used throughout the movie making it more realistic for the audience whom may be sitting in a dark theater, or a night viewing at home. This natural tone allows us to see things more clear giving the spectators a concise feel for what the characters are engaging in during the outdoor scenes. White light is used in the final scene where Tris and Four combat the enemy in the control room at the Dauntless training facility to reset the computerized mind controlling serum given to all the Dauntless characters. This is an effective way to show the audience how bright colors in a white light setting can enhance the viewer's visual perception of the environment. The story line of this action packed movie takes the viewer on the adventures of a love story, conspiracy theory, and heroic journeys of the futuristic society where five factions are the basis of the civilization.

title: The best one yet
text: I love this line from the youtube series "honest trailer" - "they had the romance of a lifetime, expressed entirely in stares" in honor of the epic Twilight love flop. And this is what I was hoping not to see again in the Divergent series. There was too much supernatural soap opera going on the last couple of years, it's the time for something much less smooching and much more plot than chasing shirtless hotties. And here it comes - yes undeniably the romance is still on, but so far much more clean and painless. Beside that, the story offers some the food for thought, the point being how you build your character when you are young and how the choices make us who we are. It is to be argued if Tris is more or less or the same level of complexity as Katniss but definitely there is much less darkness to her than to the Hunger games' heroine and I must say this is very likable. So the story is quite real to keep you invested throughout the whole 2h of it. The end is nice though not much of a cliffhanger for the next movie. But the cast delivers quite engaging performance so you would love to see them again. I really enjoyed the progress of Shailene Woodley after "The spectacular now" and I believe there are more great performances from her to come. The rest of the cast was charming as well - very hateble villains, very reliable boyfriend, dedicated friends and above all - marvelous bad, bad, bad Kate Winslet. Enjoy this new series and don't forget - the easy way tends not be the right one.

title: Good old-fashioned young adult thriller
text: "You're different. You don't fit into a category. They can't control you. They call it Divergent." Tori (Maggie Q)Does Divergent diverge from the YA formula established by the Twilight series and fattened by the Hunger Games franchise? Not much. But I have to admit I was carried along by the interesting sci-fi story and solid performances of lead Shailene Woodley (Tris) and Theo James (Four). In other words, my intellect was teased by the allegory and my heart by the true romance. Divergent is just good old-fashioned young-adult storytelling that engages adults and teens at the same time.Faced with making a choice of what category of five the teen chooses to belong to for a lifetime (Erudite, Candor, Amity, Dauntless, and Abnegation) Tris chooses the protector group Dauntless, while knowing she doesn't fit any (that's why she's "Divergent") group. Already you can see the author, Veronica Roth, has allegory in mind, viz., a caste system that freezes people forever in a category (surely a great fear of teenagers) and a social order that allows similarities to flourish but individuality not.The Katniss of Divergent, Tris (shortened from Beatrice, an allusion, perhaps, to Dante's guide into hell), is not as glamorous as Katniss (but then that's relative since Jennifer Lawrence is not a classic beauty either), nor as skilled initially, but she has a reserve and humility, as well as interior demons, that can endear her to the audiences' sense of their own flawed humanity.Like other young adult fiction, Divergent plays to teen fears and a societal concern about stifling individuality. By overcoming the former and becoming who she is meant to be for the latter, Tris embodies the ideals of a healthy democracy and individuality. And as Woodley plays her, a normal teen with normal hang-ups and some abnormal potential. Just don't buy into the airbrushed posters with her perfect bod—she's only fairly good looking and fairly flawed.If that's not enough to get you to this actioner, see Kate Winslet play a bad Erudite named Jeanine—she's quite believable and quite different from her carefully framed persona of a simpering goodie. Wait. Wait. She is expressing her individuality as a talented actress. She's divergent!"The system removes the threat of anyone exercising their independent will. Divergents threaten that system. It won't be safe until they're removed." Jeanine (Kate Winslet)

title: An adaptation that is very okay, v1.00.
text: The biggest problem that this film series faces is that it is based on some very long and delicious novels. The Hunger Games series shows that the features can still be okay, but that is not the same as 'delicious'.So I experience Divergent to be very okay. It is an adaptation rather than a straight copy and the two commentaries with my disk do help me see why the adaptations were made. A lot of the film can feel natural, even though such as The Pit is rather different to the book.The film makers / director are / is, not surprisingly, very visually orientated rather than technically orientated and to me this is the root of the main problems that I experience in Divergent the film. To fully experience most features films one has to suspend disbelief, which can take a bit of work. Mostly with Divergent I find it easy to suspend disbelief, but I had not read the novels for about a year prior to my first viewing.With the feature Super 8, the train crash is deliberately visually orientated to an unreal extent and its commentary says why. Divergent: My biggest problem, first viewing, was the zip line ride from the Hancock building. Visuals gone wild at the expense of reality. Try such a ride in even a less windy city would be asking to get smeared on the buildings that are passed. Building such a ride would not be so easy for such a society, either. Yet the novels feel very real in their depictions of the ride. The Abnegation underwear of Tris, a more humorous piece of unreality.There are plenty of other parts of the story where the visuals are too hotted up for my taste, becoming unreal, but to point to them can easily get in the way of appreciation of the film.I get the descriptor 'delicious' from that magnificent second childhood story Ramona And Beezus.
